The issue before the Court is not whether the VRA worked in the past, but whether it should continue as a limit on state sovereignty today. States have the power to regulate voting, and the VRA created exceptions to the scheme in the Constitution premised on a finding of extremely discriminatory voting laws and practices in 9 states. The conditions that were present in those states no longer exist. All of these states have elected black and other minority officials at all levels of state government. The question is whether these states require the extraordinary practice of requiring the Justice Department to approve their election laws. 41 other states do not require this action. I fail to see any connection between campaign finance laws (which benefit both national parties and the VRA.

As to "nighmares of the past," you cannot demonstrate that any of the extreme practices and laws that existed in 1965 exist today. Nor is the comparison to life in the 1890s relevant. No one is arguing that separate but equal is appropriate in America. The better question is why states like Texas require federal oversight while Oklahoma does not.

It occurs to me that a democracy with as proud of a heritage as ours should have anybody trying to rig the system so that they can get voted in instead of the candidates that the people want.  Political parties, politicians, and entities that do this are almost tantamount to enemies of the state because they are trying to destroy our system of government and way of life.  What if the poor could do this?  What if all of a sudden the people that the wealthy want disenfranchised were able to make it illegal for rich people to vote?  This, of course, has never happened and it probably never will.  Why the Supreme court would strike down a law that has been working good for the past 41 years doesn't even make sense, unless you tie it into their decision to let corporations and the wealthy spend as much as they want to influence elections.  We are living with the nightmares of America's past who have come back to haunt us.  Do we have to fight this fight again?  If these people keep pushing the buttons of the majority of the people of this country they may have a fight that they cannot ever win.  It is time to start on the offensive against all of this blather to take us back to the 1890's in this country.  This is bad for the country because the rest of the world is progressing at a rapid rate - and they are surpassing this country.  The 1% had better come to their senses before we don't have a viable country anymore to turn the clock back on!

Actually, we do suffer from too much food. The industrial crops of corn and soy, subsidized by the government and grown by big ag, cause all manner of ill health in the form of junk food stacked in the aisles of the grocery stores, with multi million dollar ad campaigns to sell them.

"impressive increases in yield can be achieved by means of crop diversification, integrated pest management, and nutrient cycling."

That is really just an expansion of scientific farming ideas that made headway from the late 1700's. The article says that fully half of all farming still has not joined that.

In the 1960's a Green Revolution provided better seeds too, wheat and rice plants that had more food per plant, and that grew better under less than perfect conditions. I assume the author approves of that, varieties of wheat and rice that have more grains per stalk for example, or are more tolerant of variations in rain and heat.

Now we see a suggestion that more of what worked for half of all farms should be applied to the other half, instead of yet another revolution to high input farming that would increase yield for those already most productive.

There is nothing either/or in this. We can and should do both. High end farming can produce more. Low end farming can produce more.

Another way to look at it is low end farming will use more input available to them, labor and land, instead of fuel and pesticides and massive overuse of fertilizer, and high cost seed available only from Big Ag. Help them do that. If our own farmers can also get lower prices by a different set of inputs, let them do that too.

While it may be true that nobody starves today because food cannot be produced, it is also true that we do not suffer today from too much food.

This is a lawless decision. First, there is no unconstitutionality. The 15th amendment is more specific and more recent than the 10th, as well as the "state equality" notion the court also relies on. Second, a law duly enacted pursuant to constitutional authorization may be found unconstitutional only if it lacks a "rational basis," meaning any factual support. The court does not and cannot make that claim here.

Arrogant, activist--add your own term. This is "unequal justice under no law."

The real judicial sleight of hand here is that the court turned away this act based on the premise that those states for whom this act was created have improved their behaviors the problem is no longer contained in geographically define political subdivisions but has spread out like a cancer within a political party, the GOP.  The same fundamental behaviors that were once contained in the South are now present in every GOP governed state.  There is a disease in our democracy and it is the stranglehold of giant corporations using the GOP to milk America like a cash cow.  Today is just one more cog in the grinding wheel.

"The Court did not legislate this result, it simply stated that the facts that existed in 1965 do not exist today."

***
The VRA has become symbolic. There is a special affection for the VRA and its role in eliminating discrimination. The emotional reaction to this decision seems to stem from the perception that this decision is a blow to the principles on which it was based.

It is not just about African American voters; it is the principle; and if you look at Texas and Arizonas' tactics to prohibit minorities and the disenfranchised from voting over the last few years -- the legislation the Supreme Court just struck down was not out of date!

The Court followed standard Constitutional analysis by requiring that the Act has a rational basis. To demonstrate continued Constitutional viability, Congress must provide facts (legislative findings) demonstrating there are discriminatory voting practices in the affected states. There are black elected leaders in all of these states. The law was enacted almost TWO generations ago. The majority observed these and other obvious facts demonstrate that the legislative basis for the law is no longer viable.

This law curtailed state sovereignty (explicitly protected in the Constitution), so the Court had to look at the factual basis for the law. The federal government is a limited government, whose powers were conferred in the Constitution. The Court said provide a list of facts existing today that justify this law.

The Court did not legislate this result, it simply stated that the facts that existed in 1965 do not exist today. The Court did not say Congress could not pass a new VRA, it said pass a revised VRA with Congressional findings demonstrating the basis for the law.

Recall that the Administration and Congress (completely controlled by the Democrats until 2011) refused to enact a new VRA with findings that there are conditions that exist today that justify this law. Those who wanted to extend this legislation knew they could not marshal the facts. Blame them, not the Court. They were warned they did not have the facts, and chose to ignore the warning.

I would have made this a "Times Pick." We need facts beyond what the media  is handed by corporations to disseminate so that we can make informed choices on these critical issues. Thanks for the useful comment.

I wish you would link to a more credible article comparing natural gas vs. coal- methane gas leakage rates are extraordinarily imprecise as it's completely dependent on the methodology and execution of fracking, and transportation is required for all fossil fuel collection methods. And while fracking has its issues, I don't see how it could be more destructive than coal mining.

Regardless of the argument on how much "cleaner" natural gas is on a GHG basis in comparison to coal, the fact of the matter is that the US needs to get off of coal, even if it means simply switching to another fossil fuel. Most arguments against the use of natural gas fails to credit the fact that it is significantly cleaner burning in terms of soot and particulate emissions, which are carcinogenic and directly cause health and environmental damage. As a valley Californian, you should be familiar with the concept of smog and its disastrous effects on health.

Obama has actually put together a comprehensive plan that is grounded in reality. For one- the recognition that the East needs to contribute significantly in order to maintain or decrease emissions. For another, the fact that the country cannot be weaned off all fossil fuels overnight and requires a measured approach, creative approach to move way. And lastly, the acknowledgement that we are already on the verge of, if not IN a "runaway greenhouse" situation. Mass extinction or not, the earth will go on if we don't act, just maybe not us.

I'm disappointed to see Gillis repeat the discredited rumor that natural gas powered electricity produces half the greenhouse gas emissions of coal. When methane leaks from gas drilling and transport are included, there is no global warming advantage to switching from coal to gas:

http://thinkprogress.org/climate/2013/01/02/1388021/bridge-to-nowhere-no...

Fossil fuel and banking firms are horizontally integrated, and have succeeded in selling the gas "bridge fuel" nonsense as a way to segue from coal.

It's also no big accomplishment that American emissions have declined. They remain very high on a per capita basis, double most countries in Europe, and triple those of Sweden.

We need to stop burning all fossil fuels to produce electricity if the world is to avoid a runaway greenhouse. American inertia and bribery of Congress has stalled progress on a global level, especially since major solar plant construction in the Mojave was sabotaged. Solar, wind, and geothermal are here, and dropping in cost every year. It's time to deploy them, and for American to return to its traditional role as a moral and technological leader.

Obama may indeed be helpless to motivate Congress to act, but nibbling at the edges is doomed. Today was a good first step, but we need much, much more, or we face a runaway greenhouse, and possible mass extinction.

John:

In case you missed it, poll taxes are ILLEGAL.
Making paying income tax a test for voting is also ILLEGAL.

Think about it.

You are saying that in some year when you don't earn enough to be obliged to pay taxes means you lose your right to vote.

If Mitt Romney got his way, by your rule, he would be barred from voting, because all of his "income" would be sheltered from tax.

Is that what you are saying??

That makes ZERO sense, and has NO basis in law.

By that reasoning, the owners of GE and other corporations who don't pay income tax should not be allowed to vote, either, since this court decided that corporations are people.

Your criteria is not one of the conditions required by the constitution. The conditions are that you are a US citizen,18+ years old, and a legal resident.

I suspect I'm wasting my breath talking to someone who calls people "moocher class", because you're mind is already made up. But I'm not going to assume my suspicion is correct and not try. Not paying income tax only means you earn below a certain amount of money. It does not mean you don't pay taxes. There are sales taxes and tons of government "fees" added on to your utility bills, and so on. It also does not mean you're not hard-working. Many people who don't pay income taxes work several jobs, but their wages are so low that it doesn't go over the threshold that divides too poor from needing to pay something.

If you're not closeminded, read Barbara Ehrenreich's book "Nickel and Dimed". It's an eye-opener for those who have never tried to support themselves and their families on low-wage jobs. Ms. Ehrenreich went to work in those jobs held by those you call "moocher class". During this time, she lived on what she made. I think you'll be surprised at what it's like to be one of those people you feel so superior to. Do you have what it takes to be one, if a tragedy in your life sends you there?

It's too bad that the Supreme Court did not limit voting to people who actually pay Federal Income Tax.  Why should an ever increasing moocher class be able to negate the votes of hard-working taxpayers.   Perhaps one day.
Today's Supreme Court ruling on voting rights is a victory for those that work for a living over those who vote for a living.
